title: Australia news live: Aboriginal man, 24, dies after being restrained by police at Alice Springs supermarket
snippets:
Follow today’s news live

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Former Labor minister Ed Husic has called for the government to move beyond words to action, and said sanctions on Israel are “probably under consideration”.

After Anthony Albanese on Monday said Israel’s blockade of aid into Gaza was “an outrage”, Husic said the prime minister’s comments were important but the government should do “whatever we can”. He told ABC Radio National:

We’ve got to the threshold where there’s an expectation we move beyond words … We should be speaking up, but beyond speaking up, I think it’s important that we act, and I certainly think it’s vital our government joins with others to be able to do that.

The third area I think we should be actively considering, and I suspect it’s probably under consideration, is drawing up a list of targeted sanctions where we can join with others … we should be ready to move when others move as well, to be able to exert maximum international pressure to stop this blockade and to help people in Gaza.

Getting dairy backs and productive is important. Getting them back to pre-flood is not about days and weeks. This is months and longer to really see these enterprises back where they want to be.

Floods come along and they’re devastating but they capture attention and we respond to that. Drought is different but the pain those people are experiencing is just as great as on the mid-north Coast and other places. …

The key thing is they need the short-term help but they really need to be able to hear from our industry and government and leaders that support will be ongoing. It shouldn’t just run out when the headlines fade, but be there for the long time.

Continue reading...

titles: Australia news live: Aboriginal man, 24, dies after being restrained by police at Alice Springs supermarket
Australia news live: Aboriginal man, 24, dies after being restrained by police at Alice Springs supermarket
summary: Former Labor minister Ed Husic has urged the Australian government to take action beyond just verbal condemnation regarding Israel's blockade of aid into Gaza, suggesting that sanctions against Israel are likely being considered. Following Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's statement labeling the blockade as "an outrage," Husic emphasized on ABC Radio National the importance of moving from words to action, including the potential for targeted sanctions in collaboration with other nations. Additionally, Husic highlighted the need for long-term support for dairy farmers affected by floods, stress
constructiveness_reason: The story provides useful information about the ongoing issue of police brutality and the need for government action. However, it doesn't provide solutions or report on improvements, limiting its score.

title: Liverpool parade collision: what we know so far
snippets:
A man has been arrested after a car ploughed into the crowd at Liverpool FC’s Premier League victory parade

  • Liverpool latest – live updates

The city of Liverpool is in shock after a car ploughed into the crowd at Liverpool FC’s Premier League title victory parade. Twenty-seven people were taken to hospital and 20 others were treated at the scene. Four children were among the injured. At least four people, including one of the children, are said to have sustained serious injuries.

Merseyside police said a 53-year-old white male from the Liverpool area was arrested at the scene. At a late-night press conference, the force’s assistant chief constable Jenny Sims said the “horrific incident” was not being treated as terrorism.

Continue reading...
titles: Liverpool parade collision: what we know so far
summary: A man was arrested after driving into a crowd during Liverpool FC's Premier League victory parade, injuring 27 people, with 20 more treated on-site. Four children were among the injured, with at least four individuals sustaining serious injuries. The 53-year-old suspect from Liverpool is in custody. The incident, causing shock in the city, is not being treated as terrorism, according to Merseyside police.
constructiveness_reason: While the story offers basic awareness about the incident, it lacks depth or insight into the causes, potential solutions, or broader implications of the event.

title: More interstate dust storms expected if South Australia drought continues, expert warns
snippets:
Haze hits Sydney suburbs on Tuesday morning after crossing NSW from SA and Victoria

  • Australia news live: latest politics updates

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Parts of Sydney faced “extremely poor” air quality warnings on Tuesday morning as a dust storm swept eastwards from inland Australia.

Sydney’s north-west and central west including Parramatta had the heaviest air pollution, with very poor air quality also observed across Sydney stretching as far south as Goulburn and as far north as Muswellbrook, according to official pollution monitoring stations.

Continue reading...

titles: More interstate dust storms expected if South Australia drought continues, expert warns
More interstate dust storms expected if South Australia drought continues, expert warns
summary: On Tuesday morning, Sydney suburbs experienced haze and "extremely poor" air quality due to a dust storm that traveled from South Australia and Victoria, across New South Wales. The most affected areas were Sydney's north-west and central west, including Parramatta, with significant air pollution also reported as far south as Goulburn and as far north as Muswellbrook. This information was confirmed by official pollution monitoring stations.
constructiveness_reason: This news story is constructive as it provides useful insights about the ongoing drought and its impact on air quality. It raises awareness about the potential for further dust storms if the drought continues, which could help readers make informed decisions about their health and safety. However, it lacks a focus on solutions or innovations to address the problem.

title: Here's how many fake reviews Tripadvisor found on its website in 2024
snippets: Around 8% of the 31.1 million reviews submitted to Tripadvisor in 2024 were fake. That's twice the number detected in 2022, according to a company report.
titles: Here's how many fake reviews Tripadvisor found on its website in 2024
summary: In 2024, Tripadvisor reported that 8% of its 31.1 million reviews, amounting to approximately 2.5 million, were identified as fake. This figure represents a significant increase from 2022, where the detection rate was half of that. The company actively monitors and removes fraudulent content to maintain the integrity of its platform.
constructiveness_reason: The story provides useful information about the prevalence of fake reviews on Tripadvisor and the company's efforts to combat this issue. It contributes to the reader's understanding of the integrity of online reviews, although it does not highlight any new solutions or innovations.

title: Why ChatGPT’s Essays Don’t Fool the Experts – Yet
snippets: A study reveals who writes better, and it turns out, it’s not the AI. Artificial intelligence has yet to match the quality of real student writing, according to new research from the University of East Anglia (UK). In a study published in the journal Written Communication, researchers compared essays written by 145 students to those [...]
titles: Why ChatGPT’s Essays Don’t Fool the Experts – Yet
summary: A study from the University of East Anglia, published in the journal Written Communication, found that artificial intelligence, specifically AI like ChatGPT, does not yet match the quality of essays written by real students. The research involved comparing essays from 145 students with those generated by AI, concluding that human writing remains superior in quality.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful insights into the current state of AI technology, particularly in the context of writing. It helps readers understand the limitations of AI and provides a basis for comparison between human and AI writing. However, it does not report on solutions or improvements, nor does it significantly increase awareness around systems or impacts.

title: This Ultrasonic Tech Can Charge Devices Through Water
snippets: A research team from KIST and Korea University has developed a biocompatible ultrasonic receiver. As demand grows for underwater and implantable medical electronics, ensuring a stable and continuous power supply has become increasingly important. Traditional wireless charging methods, such as electromagnetic induction and radio frequency-based systems commonly used in smartphones and earbuds, face several challenges. [...]
titles: This Ultrasonic Tech Can Charge Devices Through Water
summary: Researchers from KIST and Korea University have created a biocompatible ultrasonic receiver that can charge devices underwater and power implantable medical electronics. This new technology addresses the limitations of traditional wireless charging methods, like electromagnetic induction and radio frequency systems, which struggle with efficiency and safety in underwater environments and within the human body. This advancement promises a more reliable power supply for a range of applications.
constructiveness_reason: The story reports on a significant innovation in the field of wireless charging technology. It offers readers a deeper understanding of the limitations of current technologies and how this new development addresses those issues. It also highlights the potential applications of this technology, contributing to the reader's sense of agency.

title: Scientists Develop New Solar Device That Squeezes Water From Air
snippets: A new sponge-like material uses sunlight to harvest water from air, offering an efficient, low-cost solution for water scarcity. Engineers from Australia and China have developed a sponge-like device that captures moisture from the air and releases it into a cup using solar energy. Unlike other technologies such as fog harvesting and radiative cooling, this [...]
titles: Scientists Develop New Solar Device That Squeezes Water From Air
summary: Scientists from Australia and China have created a sponge-like device that efficiently extracts water from the air using solar energy. This low-cost, innovative technology provides a new solution to address water scarcity by capturing moisture and releasing it into a container, offering an alternative to existing methods like fog harvesting and radiative cooling.
constructiveness_reason: This news story clearly highlights progress and offers empowering knowledge. It reports on an innovative solution to address water scarcity, providing readers with a deeper understanding of the issue and the new technology. It also increases awareness around the potential impacts of this development.

title: Few diffusers and many bottlenecks: The French labor market according to statistical physics
snippets: How long have you been doing your current job? Have you ever thought about trying a new profession? How difficult does change seem to you? The current rapid transformation of the labor market is putting many workers to the test: they struggle to keep up and move into new roles, while at the same time, companies are having difficulty finding qualified personnel.
titles: Few diffusers and many bottlenecks: The French labor market according to statistical physics
summary: The labor market is undergoing a rapid transformation, challenging workers to adapt to new roles and companies to find qualified personnel. This dynamic is testing the adaptability of the workforce and the recruitment capabilities of businesses, highlighting a significant shift in employment trends and demands.
constructiveness_reason: The story provides useful insights about the changing dynamics of the labor market, which can help readers understand the current employment trends and demands. However, it doesn't offer any solutions or progress towards addressing these challenges.

title: Middle-Age Hearing Loss Could Accelerate Cognitive Decline
snippets: A study tracking 805 Brazilians in their 50s over an eight-year period has concluded that greater focus on hearing health may play a crucial role in preventing dementia. A major study from Brazil has found that people in their 50s with hearing loss face a greater risk of cognitive decline. The findings, published in the [...]
titles: Middle-Age Hearing Loss Could Accelerate Cognitive Decline
summary: A Brazilian study tracking 805 individuals in their 50s over eight years found that hearing loss may increase the risk of cognitive decline, suggesting that better attention to hearing health could help prevent dementia.
constructiveness_reason: This story offers empowering knowledge by linking hearing health to cognitive decline, which could potentially lead to dementia. This information is actionable as it encourages readers to pay more attention to their hearing health as a preventative measure.
